How beautiful<S>3302</S> are thy feet<S>6471</S> with shoes<S>5275</S>, O prince's<S>5081</S> daughter<S>1323</S>! the joints<S>2542</S> of thy thighs<S>3409</S> are like jewels<S>2481</S>, the work<S>4639</S> of the hands<S>3027</S> of a cunning workman<S>542</S>.
Thy navel<S>8326</S> is like a round<S>5469</S> goblet<S>101</S>, which wanteth<S>2637</S> not liquor<S>4197</S>: thy belly<S>990</S> is like an heap<S>6194</S> of wheat<S>2406</S> set about<S>5473</S> with lilies<S>7799</S>. <sup>liquor: Heb. mixture</sup>
Thy two<S>8147</S> breasts<S>7699</S> are like two<S>8147</S> young<S>6082</S> roes<S>6646</S> that are twins<S>8380</S>.
Thy neck<S>6677</S> is as a tower<S>4026</S> of ivory<S>8127</S>; thine eyes<S>5869</S> like the fishpools<S>1295</S> in Heshbon<S>2809</S>, by the gate<S>8179</S> of Bathrabbim<S>1337</S>: thy nose<S>639</S> is as the tower<S>4026</S> of Lebanon<S>3844</S> which looketh<S>6822</S> toward<S>6440</S> Damascus<S>1834</S>.
Thine head<S>7218</S> upon thee is like Carmel<S>3760</S>, and the hair<S>1803</S> of thine head<S>7218</S> like purple<S>713</S>; the king<S>4428</S> is held<S>631</S> in the galleries<S>7298</S>. <sup>Carmel: or, crimson</sup> <sup>held: Heb. bound</sup>
How fair<S>3302</S> and how pleasant<S>5276</S> art thou, O love<S>160</S>, for delights<S>8588</S>!
This thy stature<S>6967</S> is like<S>1819</S> to a palm tree<S>8558</S>, and thy breasts<S>7699</S> to clusters<S>811</S> of grapes.
I said<S>559</S>, I will go up<S>5927</S> to the palm tree<S>8558</S>, I will take hold<S>270</S> of the boughs<S>5577</S> thereof: now also thy breasts<S>7699</S> shall be as clusters<S>811</S> of the vine<S>1612</S>, and the smell<S>7381</S> of thy nose<S>639</S> like apples<S>8598</S>;
And the roof of thy mouth<S>2441</S> like the best<S>2896</S> wine<S>3196</S> for my beloved<S>1730</S>, that goeth<S>1980</S> down sweetly<S>4339</S>, causing the lips<S>8193</S> of those that are asleep<S>3463</S> to speak<S>1680</S>. <sup>sweetly: Heb. straightly</sup> <sup>of those: or, of the ancient</sup>
I am my beloved's<S>1730</S>, and his desire<S>8669</S> is toward me.
Come<S>3212</S>, my beloved<S>1730</S>, let us go forth<S>3318</S> into the field<S>7704</S>; let us lodge<S>3885</S> in the villages<S>3723</S>.
Let us get up early<S>7925</S> to the vineyards<S>3754</S>; let us see<S>7200</S> if the vine<S>1612</S> flourish<S>6524</S>, whether the tender grape<S>5563</S> appear<S>6605</S>, and the pomegranates<S>7416</S> bud forth<S>5132</S>: there will I give<S>5414</S> thee my loves<S>1730</S>. <sup>appear: Heb. open</sup>
The mandrakes<S>1736</S> give<S>5414</S> a smell<S>7381</S>, and at our gates<S>6607</S> are all manner of pleasant<S>4022</S> fruits, new<S>2319</S> and old<S>3465</S>, which I have laid up<S>6845</S> for thee, O my beloved<S>1730</S>.
